name: Kepler-263
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-263 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-263 is a star with 0.685 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.79 times its radius. It is located 2514.96 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-263 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-263 b

Kepler-263 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 16.57 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-263.

The mass of Kepler-263 b is 10.14 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-263 b is 2.67 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-263 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-263 c

Kepler-263 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 47.33 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-263.

The mass of Kepler-263 c is 8.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-263 c is 2.47 that of Earth. At 8.39 Earth masses, Kepler-263 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-263, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
